meta_data.title: A Mental Map of Nehemiah's Jerusalem
meta_data.subtitle: Nehemiah 3:13-32 Thanks to everyone who supports TMBH at  You're the reason we can all do this together!  Music by

transcription_data.text: Hey, my friends, it's Matt. This is a 10 minute Bible Hour podcast and I don't know if you are like me or not, but this is definitely a thing about the way my brain works. But I love me a good mental map. I enjoy being able to picture a place that I'm reading about. If I'm reading some kind of fantasy book, I'll always thumb over to the map and keep checking back on that. Okay, I got my little ruler out. It'd be about this far from there to there because it's just fascinating to me. The relationship between time and space and geography and people and lifespan, travel times, all of that stuff adds up to understanding. It's a huge part of our lives. So I'm having a really tough time, truth to be told, with Nehemiah 3, because there's a ton of details being thrown at me. The names of a whole bunch of people happen in real fast and a whole bunch of locations around this reduced version of what Jerusalem had been prior to the time of Nehemiah, that Nehemiah is trying to enclose. And so I went and did a little digging around it, looking at some of my other Bibles that have cool maps. There's one that I really like, the ESV study Bible by Crossway. They have cool maps. Cool graphics. So I went there and they did not let me down on page 828 of my ESV study Bible. There's this beautiful drawing of the little sliver of Jerusalem that Nehemiah is trying to put back together here. And I think as we pick it up where we left off last time, I think we got through 12 verses of Nehemiah 3 last time, we're going to do the rest of the chapter today. I think as we pick it up, we're going to be able to make a mental map. It might not be perfect. It might not work for you. But cheating off of this really nice art and lining it up next to the actual text that we're reading, I think it's going to help us both a whole bunch. So let me just pick it up right where we left off last time around. So I think we're starting with verse 13 of Nehemiah 3. And let's see if just for one day, just one day, we can try to visualize the geography of this. And then when we get into chapter four, which we'll get to tomorrow, the drama will fire back up. So all right. We're picking it up in Nehemiah 3, 13, working our way around the city, building a mental map. Here we go. The valley gate was repaired by Hanun and the residents of Zanoa. They rebuilt it and put its doors and bolts and bars in place. They also repaired 500 yards of the wall as far as the dungate. The dungate was repaired by Melkaija, son of Rekhab, ruler of the district of Beth Hakarem. We built it and put its doors and bolts and bars in place. This is what I'm detecting at this point now as I look at this map. Maybe this will help you picture it. Let's imagine that we're looking at a map of Italy. Stick with me. This might make sense. And up at the top, you know how Italy kind of flares? It's like the boot has flair at the top, the hip or whatever. And then down at the bottom, of course, you got the kicking part of the boot that kicks the island of Sicily and you got the heel. So imagine that the city of Jerusalem that Nehemiah is trying to wall in and repair is like a map of Italy with a flared boot part up at the top up in the north by Bolzano, Verona, Milan, all that stuff's way up north. And up there is where the temple is. So like getting up toward Switzerland and Germany and that's Austria up there. That's where the temple is, way up at the top of the boot. And then the middle part of the boot is real long and it goes way down. And then you get a toe to the boot and that's where the dungate is. You can remember that because what do you kick dung with? The toe of your boat, right? Like you don't turn your foot sideways and kick it with the inside like a soccer kick. I hope you don't. Gross. Use the toe of the boot. So the toe of the boot is the dungate and then there is no heel. Here's just forget the heel. And if you have that in mind, then I think Nehemiah chapter three might have a mental map that will work. It looks like this list starts with the first geographic place being the sheep gate. Now, as I'm looking at my map of where the sheep gate is, that is right next to the temple, like right at the temple. So the author of Nehemiah here looks like these are probably the memoirs of Nehemiah himself is starting at 12 o'clock, if you will, right at the north central point of the Italy boot far, far away from the toe where the temple is. The temple is all the way up north at the top of the boot where it flares. Got it. Now we're going to go counterclockwise. It looks like down what would be, I guess this would be the west side of this very long narrow Jerusalem city that Nehemiah is trying to enclose. And we're going to go down that and we're going to go around the tip and you remember what the tip is, right? At the city, it's the dungate. It's memorable because you kick the dung with the sea. I mean, it's ridiculous. And maybe you're rolling your eyes and maybe you're not going to forget it. See, you're not going to forget it. It's going to stick with you. The dumber thing is the more memorable it is. And then we're going to go around the tip of the boot, the dungate, and we're going to go back up. And it seems like the author here is just taking us on a tour counterclockwise from the far northern point all the way down to the tip and then all the way back up the east side and back around to where we started at the sheep gate. So we're going sheep gate and the very next thing in verse still in verse one that got fixed was the tower of the hundred. I don't know what that was. And then the tower of Hana-Nel, we're kind of coming around the corner, the fish gate, the gate of Yeshana, the gate of Ephraim, the tower of the ovens. I think that sounds really interesting. I don't know what that means. Now we're kind of down into the armpit of Italy by the time we get to the tower of the ovens. And now we're going all the way down the long, straight part of the boot on the Roman coast. And it looks like the western hill, the central valley, those would be somewhere around where Rome is on the boot in the middle. Let me go all the way down to the pool of Siloam and the dungate, which we run into in verse 14. So going up through verse 14, there's a lot of these accounts that don't have anything to do with a specific gate or a specific tower. It's like they just did this chunk wall. These people, this perfumer did that much wall. This goldsmith did that much wall, not a lot of gates on that western side. Then we get down to the tip, we get to the dungate, which we just read about. We round the corner toward the fountain gate. Smart people seem to think that the fountain gate might somehow be connected to the pool of Siloam, which is down on the tip of the boot all the way down south here. And that that pool was used for water supply for the city for a really long time. Maybe the fountain gate had something to do with that. And that's where we pick it up in verse 15. Are you mental mapping with me? Is it working? I don't know. If it doesn't, it's only one episode. We're going to do our best. The fountain gate was repaired by Shalun son of Col Jose, ruler of the district of Mizpa. He rebuilt it, roofing it over and putting its doors and bolts and bars in place. He also repaired the wall of the pool of Siloam. We know that that got wrecked during Nebuchadnezzar's destruction in 586 BC, 140 years, almost exactly before the stuff we're reading about here in Nehemiah. So okay, also repaired the walls of the pool of Siloam by the king's garden as far as the steps going down from the city of David. Ah, well, I've been to Jerusalem before. It's pretty hard for me to overlay a mental map of Nehemiah's Jerusalem over the top of whatever 2020 Jerusalem is just very, very different. But I can orient a little bit by where the temple is and where the city of David is and kind of how you go downhill there. So I can feel this a little bit. Maybe if you've been there, you can feel it better beyond him. Nehemiah son of Osbuk, no relation, different Nehemiah, ruler of a half district of Beth Zur made repairs up to a point opposite the tombs of David as far as the artificial pools and the house of heroes. That place sounds awesome. I don't see that on my map. I don't know where this is. The house of heroes is somewhere on the east side of the boot. Now, as we are going back up toward northern Italy on the east side, it's somewhere. That place sounds rad. Maybe this is where if it's by David's tomb, maybe this is where David's mighty men got buried. I mean, that'd be pretty cool. I'm shooting from the hip here. I have no idea. Next to him, the repairs were made by the Levites under Rehum son of Bani beside him, Hoshabaya, ruler of the half district of K'la, carried out repairs for his district next to him. The repairs were made by their countrymen under B'newai, son of Henedad, ruler of the other half district of K'la. Next to him, Azer, son of Joshua, ruler of Mizpa, repaired another section from a point facing the ascent to the armory as far as the angle. Aha! Now I'm located again. All right. I got a sense of where we are. We've gone clear back up the boot on the east side of Italy. We're about at Venice. And now we're going to turn back east a little bit where it flares out and it gets wide up here on the Temple Hill, the Temple Mount area. All right. Now where were we next to him? Baruch, son of Zebai, zealously repaired another section from the angle to the entrance of the house of Elia Shiba, the high priest. Oh, that's the guy who we met in chapter 3 verse 1. Elia Shiba, the high priest and his fellow priests went to work. Okay. So yeah, it's all kind of hanging together here. Let's bring it home. Next to him, Marimoth, son of Aria, son of Hakaz repaired another section from the entrance of Elia Shiba's house to the end of it. The repairs next to him were made by the high priest from the surrounding region. Beyond them, Benjamin and Haschub made repairs in front of the house and next to them Azariah, son of Masaya, the son of Ananiya, made repairs beside his house next to him. Benoai, son of Henedad, repaired another section from Azariah's house to the angle and the corner and Palal, son of Zai, worked opposite the angle and the tower projecting from the upper palace near the court of the guard next to him, Padaya, son of Purash and the temple servants living on the hill of Othel, made repairs up to a point opposite the water gate toward the east end of the projecting tower. Cool. So we are clear up now. We're starting around the corner. We're on the big bend coming back around toward the temple on the northeast end of this big Italy boot shaped thing. And maybe at this point, you're looking at the time and you're like, dang, are we really going to finish these next few verses and just be done with this all in one day in the answer is yes. And maybe you're starting to feel a little bit bored. You're like, that is a lot of names. And now I would like to completely shame you. How dare you feel bored? These people busted their butts to fix Jerusalem and played their part in preserving God's redemptive plan. That's very disrespectful for you have been bored or to be scrolling, Twitter, goofing around while I'm reading off their names. I'm mostly joking, but at the same time, yeah, I think these people deserve to be honored. They did something nobody had been able to do for generations. They pulled together. They did a thing. They did a montage. They got actual work done that actually needed to be accomplished. And I think it's awesome. Still, I understand it's a lot of names I totally get. And I'm still going to finish it today. Here we go. I don't remember if I read this part yet, but we're going to keep going next to them. Verse 27, the men of Tacoa repaired another section from the great projecting tower to the wall of Othel above the horse gate. The priests made repairs each in front of his own house. Like note, the horse gate is all the way at the extreme northeast corner of this whole mental map. Verse 29, next to them, Zedak son of Imair made repairs opposite his house next to him. Shimeaiah son of Shekaniah the guard at the east gate made repairs next to him. Hananiah son of Shelamaya and Hanun the sixth son of Zalaph repaired another section next to them. Mashaalum and Barakiah made repairs opposite his living quarters next to him. Melkaija one of the goldsmiths made repairs as far as the house of the temple servants and the merchants bringing it home now opposite the inspection gate and as far as the room above the corner and between the room above the corner and the sheep gate, the goldsmiths and merchants made repairs. The end as chapter three, we just did one big gigantic loop around basically an Italy shaped city from the very tippy top north central part all the way down around the tip of the boot, which is of course, as you know, say it out loud with me, the dungate. We skipped the heel because there is no heel that would be where the fountain gate is, but there's there's no heel there. You can picture a heel splashing down in a fountain or a puddle to remember that that's where the fountain gate went, but there's no heel there. So just, you know, kind of fill in the gaps. Then we went all the way back up the boot. We went around the corner and back into the place where the temple servants worked back to the temple. There's your whole lap. These people's names have been honored on this podcast between you and me. Nehemiah wanted them to be remembered. I believe God is behind the Bible and that it communicates what he wants to. So apparently God wanted these names to be remembered as well and granted it's tough to string together a really dynamic narrative for all of that. But I think we gave it fair treatment and I've built a little bit better mental map than I had before. On to chapter four. Next time around I'm Matt. This is the 10 minute Bible Hour podcast. Let's do this again soon.

<title>NEH053 - A Mental Map of Nehemiah's Jerusalem</title>
